dc:description:
*SFTPC* was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant SFTPC-related interstitial lung disease (MONDO:0018603) in 2001 (Nogee LM et al., 2001 PMID:11207353). SFTPC-related ILD is a genetic disorder that affects the lungs. It is caused by variants in the *SFTPC* gene, which encodes a protein that is important for the function of surfactant, a substance that lines the alveoli and helps to prevent them from collapsing. This disorder is characterized by a wide range of symptoms, from severe respiratory insufficiency in infants to adults with progressive pulmonary fibrosis. The typical presentation in infancy includes dyspnea, cough, wheezing, pulmonary infiltrates on chest radiographs, and gradual cyanosis, with or without failure to thrive (Clement A et al., 2010, PMID: 20727133).

More than 241 unique variants (e.g., synonymous, missense, in-frame indel, nonsense, frameshift) have been reported in humans by ClinVar. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level and experimental data. Seventeen variants (14 missense, 2 splice donor, 1 synonymous) that have been reported in 29 probands across 12 publications (Nogee LM, et al., 2001, PMID:11207353; Tredano M, et al., 2004, PMID:15039969; Thomas AQ, et al., 2002, PMID:1199188; van Moorsel CH, et al., 2010, PMID:20656946; Ono S, et al., 2011, PMID:21828032; Peca D, et al., 2015, PMID:25782673; Tang X et al., 2019, PMID: 32851322; Katzen J, et al., 2019, PMID: 30721158; Kazzi B, et al., 2018, PMID: 30094155; Litao MK, et al., 2017, PMID: 27362365; Fattori A, et al., 2019, PMID: 30955586; Terpe F, et al., 2023, PMID: 37232099) are included in this curation. While the precise molecular mechanism may depend on the specific variant (PMID: 22461427), the disease mechanism is related to a gain-of-toxic function. Loss-of-function (nonsense) variants have not been clearly associated with disease. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence has been reached. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by biochemical functions, tissue specific expression and animal models (GTEx Consortium, 2013, PMID: 23715323; Katzen J et al., 2019, PMID: 30721158; Nureki SI et al., 2018, PMID: 29920187; Lawson WE, et al., 2011, PMID: 21670280). 

In summary, there is definitive evidence to support the relationship between SFTPC-related interstitial lung disease. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Interstitial Lung Disease GCEP on the meeting date July 16, 2024 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description: This variant is reported in gnomAD v4.0 with a MAF=0.00002196 (2/91080 alleles) in the South Asian population.
This variant is absent from gnomAD v4.0 and v2.1.1

This variant has a MAF=0.000003597 (4/1111996 alleles) in the European (non-Finnish) population from gnomAD v4.1.0. This proband harbors 6 other variants that are classified as benign/likely benign, or have no classification, and have frequencies that are a little high. Down-scoring to be cautious.

Transfection of this variant into A549 cells showed that this alteration interferes with correct processing and routing of the final protein, as well as impaired uptake and degradation of surfactant phospholipid (PMID: 21707890).
This variant has a MAF=0.000003597 (4/1111996 alleles) in the European (non-Finnish) population from gnomAD v4.1.0

Transfection of this variant into A549 cells showed that this alteration interferes with correct processing and routing of the final protein, as well as impaired uptake and degradation of surfactant phospholipid (PMID: 21707890).
This variant has a MAF=0.000003597 (4/1111996 alleles) in the European (non-Finnish) population from gnomAD v4.1.0.

Transfection of this variant into A549 cells showed that this alteration interferes with correct processing and routing of the final protein, as well as impaired uptake and degradation of surfactant phospholipid (PMID: 21707890).
This variant is absent from Clinvar and gnomAD v2.1.1 and v4.1.0
This variant has a MAF=0.000003597 (4/1111996 alleles) in the European (non-Finnish) population from gnomAD v4.1.0.

Transfection of this variant into A549 cells showed that this alteration interferes with correct processing and routing of the final protein, as well as impaired uptake and degradation of surfactant phospholipid (PMID: 21707890).

This variant has a MAF=0.000003597 (4/1111996 alleles) in the European (non-Finnish) population from gnomAD v4.1.0. This proband harbors 2 other variants in LRBA. Down-scoring since this gene also causes lung phenotypes.

Transfection of this variant into A549 cells showed that this alteration interferes with correct processing and routing of the final protein, as well as impaired uptake and degradation of surfactant phospholipid (PMID: 21707890).
This variant is absent in gnomAD v4.0. Down-scored since parental testing was not noted to confirm de novo occurrence

Immunohistochemistry revealed abnormal localization of proSP-C in lung tissue. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) detected small and dense lamellar bodies (LBs) in type II alveolar epithelial cells (AECs). TEM of A549 cells stably expressing proSP-C L55F displayed abnormal cytoplasmic organelles (PMID: 26375473).
This proband harbors 3 other variants in genes that can cause lung phenotypes, so down-scoring to be cautious. This variant is absent from gnomAD v4.1.0 and v2.1.1.
This variant has a MAF=0.000003597 (4/1111996 alleles) in the European (non-Finnish) population from gnomAD v4.1.0.

Transfection of this variant into A549 cells showed that this alteration interferes with correct processing and routing of the final protein, as well as impaired uptake and degradation of surfactant phospholipid (PMID: 21707890).
This missense variant, p.Glu66Lys, is absent from gnomAD v4.1.0 and v2.1.1

Transfection of this variant in A549 cells showed that trafficking of the E66K mutant was markedly different, with distribution mainly in small cytosolic vesicles that were CD63 negative, EEA-1 positive consistent with accumulation in early endosomes and likely resulted in a toxic gain of function (PMID: 15557112).
This variant has a MAF=0.000003597 (4/1111996 alleles) in the European (non-Finnish) population from gnomAD v4.1.0

Transfection of this variant into A549 cells showed that this alteration interferes with correct processing and routing of the final protein, as well as impaired uptake and degradation of surfactant phospholipid (PMID: 21707890).
This variant is absent from gnomAD v4.1.0.
Transiently transfected HEK293 cells resulted in mistrafficked pro-protein and epithelial ER stress
This variant is absent from gnomAD v4.0 and v2.1.1
This variant is absent from gnomAD v2.1.1 & v4.1.0

Mouse lung epithelial (MLE12) cells transfected with plasmids containing normal and mutant SFTPC showed alveolar type II cell atypia, with numerous abnormal lamellar bodies, and exaggerated cellular toxicity.

This variant, p.Ala149Pro, is the MANE SELECT for SFTPC variant p.Arg155Pro (as labeled in paper). This variant is reported in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a MAF=0.0002745 (25/91086 alleles and 0 homozygotes) in the South Asian population..

This variant is present in gnomAD v4.1.0. MAF=0.01476 (1108/75068 alleles and 12 homozygotes) in the African/African American population. This variant is being down-scored given the high frequency and number of homozygotes.
This variant has a MAF=0.000003597 (4/1111996 alleles) in the European (non-Finnish) population from gnomAD v4.1.0

Transfection of this variant into A549 cells showed that this alteration interferes with correct processing and routing of the final protein, as well as impaired uptake and degradation of surfactant phospholipid (PMID: 21707890).

The SFTPC c.435+1G>A putative null variant is near the C terminus, so it has been down-scored. This variant is located in exon 4 out of 6 however, exon 6 is non-coding. c.435+1G>A is absent from gnomAD v2.1.1 and v4.0

Protein blotting was performed on homogenates of lung tissue from the patient. Mature surfactant protein C was undetectable in lung tissue from the patient but seen in the controls. The SFTPC variant abolishes the normal donor splice site. This mutation eliminated a recognition site for the restriction enzyme BstN1 and shows the presence of the mutation in the patient but not the controls.
This variant is absent from gnomAD v4.0 and v2.1.1

In vitro expression of the mutant gene revealed the mutation increases ER stress and induces apoptotic cell death compared with wild-type SP-C in A549 cells, supporting the significance of this mutation in the pathogenesis of pulmonary fibrosis
This variant has a MAF=0.000003597 (4/1111996 alleles) in the European (non-Finnish) population from gnomAD v4.1.0.

Transfection of this variant into A549 cells showed that this alteration interferes with correct processing and routing of the final protein, as well as impaired uptake and degradation of surfactant phospholipid (PMID: 21707890).
This variant has a MAF=0.000003597 (4/1111996 alleles) in the European (non-Finnish) population from gnomAD v4.1.0.

Transfection of this variant into A549 cells showed that this alteration interferes with correct processing and routing of the final protein, as well as impaired uptake and degradation of surfactant phospholipid (PMID: 21707890).
This variant is absent from ClinVar and reported in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a MAF=0.00006539 (1/15292 alleles and 0 homozygotes) in the Admixed American population.
This variant is near the C terminus and preserves the reading frame, so it has been down-scored.  This variant is absent from gnomAD v4.1.0.
RT-PCR RNA analysis of lung tissue showed that the IVS4+2 mutation caused a splice site alteration with subsequent deletion of exon 4 and likely results in a shortened protein product.

This variant has a MAF=0.000003597 (4/1111996 alleles) in the European (non-Finnish) population from gnomAD v4.1.0. This proband harbors 1 other variant that does not have any consequences of being disease causing for ILD.

Transfection of this variant into A549 cells showed that this alteration interferes with correct processing and routing of the final protein, as well as impaired uptake and degradation of surfactant phospholipid (PMID: 21707890).

This variant is present in gnomAD v4.1.0. MAF=0.01476 (1108/75068 alleles and 12 homozygotes) in the African/African American population. This variant is being down-scored given the high frequency and number of homozygotes.

This variant is reported in gnomAD v4.0 with a MAF=0.008372 (375/44790 alleles and 1 homozygote) in the East Asian population. This proband harbors variants in 5 other genes. Down-scoring to be cautious since some of the genes can cause lung phenotypes.

member.rdfs:label: Terpe Proband 1
member.phenotypeFreeText: A CT scan revealed diffuse infiltrates and poorly aerated areas, consistent with pneumonia. The proband received supplemental oxygen and noninvasive respiratory support. HRCT showed multiple cystic lesions suggestive of lung fibrosis. Lung transplant at 7mo. Small cholesterol granulomas

member.rdfs:label: Nogee_Case 1
member.phenotypeFreeText: Radiography of the chest showed hyperinflation with increased interstitial markings. Had open lung biopsy.

member.rdfs:label: Peca Proband 1
member.detectionMethod: PCR-based mutation analysis of the SFTPC, SFTPB and ABCA3 genes by Sanger's technique.
member.phenotypeFreeText: All subjects in the cohort had a "history of unexplained persistent or progressive diffuse lung disease based on clinical signs (abnormal auscultation, cough, dyspnea, hypoxemia) with an onset between birth and 18 years plus evidence of diffuse parenchymal lung disease." HRCT imaging shows upper lobar emphysema. Many large endosomes. Very rare lamellar bodies with abnormal phospholipid structure. Granular proSP-C pattern with diffuse large aggregates. Several amyloid deposits.
member.previousTestingDescription: Sequenced SFTPC, SFTPB and ABCA3. This proband has a synonymous coding variant (c.1383 G>A p.(Val461=)) in ABCA3 that is classified as likely benign in ClinVar.

member.rdfs:label: Proband URD25
member.phenotypeFreeText: This subpopulation who did not have evidence for lung disease, proposed environmental exposures or modifier genes to play a role in the phenotype. Liver damage without hepatic failure. Interstitial infiltrates, mediastinal lymph nodes.
member.previousTestingDescription: SFTPB mutation leading to SP-B deficiency had been ruled out

member.rdfs:label: Peca Proband 2
member.detectionMethod: PCR-based mutation analysis of the SFTPC, SFTPB and ABCA3 genes by Sanger's technique.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Multiple bronchiolitis episodes (3-12m). HRCT imagining shows multifocal interstitial infiltrates. Granular proSP-C pattern with diffuse large aggregates. Many large endosomes with some phospholipid content. Very rare immature lamellar bodies and multivesicular bodies.
member.previousTestingDescription: Sequenced SFTPC – the gene encoding SP-C – SFTPB and ABCA3, and analyzed morphology, ultrastructure and SP expression in lung tissue

member.rdfs:label: Proband URD22
member.previousTestingDescription: SFTPB mutation leading to SP-B deficiency had been ruled out

member.rdfs:label: Peca Proband 3
member.detectionMethod: PCR-based mutation analysis of the SFTPC, SFTPB and ABCA3 genes by Sanger's technique.
member.phenotypeFreeText: HRCT imaging found multiple cysts. Granular proSP-C pattern with diffuse large aggregates. Many large endosomes with phospholipid content. Very rare lamellar bodies.

evidence.rdfs:label: Ono Japanese Kindred

member.rdfs:label: Ono Proband IV-1
member.phenotypeFreeText: HRCT revealed a reticulonodular shadow and intralobular fine linear opacity predominantly in both upper lung fields. UIP pattern with marked fibroblastic foci and mild infiltration of lymphoid cells.
member.previousTestingDescription: Sequenced ATP-binding cassette, sub-family A member 3 (ABCA3; NM_001089)

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Three family members died from respiratory failure

evidence.rdfs:label: Case 4

member.rdfs:label: Peca Proband 4
member.detectionMethod: PCR-based mutation analysis of the SFTPC, SFTPB and ABCA3 genes by Sanger's technique.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Was in PICU from 18-19mos old for hypoxemia and dyspnea. HRCT imaging showed multiple subpleural nodules.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Mutation inheritance is unknown. Sibling was reported with fatal respiratory failure at 16mo and died from RDS.

member.rdfs:label: Peca Proband 7
member.phenotypeFreeText: HRCT imaging found diffuse tubular and varicose bronchiectasis, basal infiltrates.

member.rdfs:label: Peca Proband 5
member.detectionMethod: PCR-based mutation analysis of the SFTPC, SFTPB and ABCA3 genes by Sanger's technique.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Hospitalized (13-14 months old) for dyspnea and hypoxemia. Some large endosomes with phospholipid content. Rare multivesicular bodies (tracheal aspirate)

member.rdfs:label: Peca Proband 6
member.detectionMethod: PCR-based mutation analysis of the SFTPC, SFTPB and ABCA3 genes by Sanger's technique.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Lung biopsy at 14 months. HRCT imaging shows basal emphysema. Some granular proSP-C pattern plus perinuclear aggregates. Rare amyloid deposits. Numerous mitochondria, lysosomes and electron-dense deposits. Several normal lamellar bodies. Several multivesicular bodies.

member.rdfs:label: Litao Case 1
member.detectionMethod: A systematic review of the literature
member.phenotypeFreeText: Respiratory rates were between 80 and 90 breaths/min. Supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula. Significant intercostal and subcostal retractions. Her repeat chest X-ray showed an interstitial reticular pattern, and a chest CT scan showed diffuse ground glass opacities with thickened interlobular septa. At 1-years-old she received a bilateral lung transplant. Lung biopsy showed diffuse Type II pneumocyte hyperplasia and thickening of the alveolar interstitium with increased cellularity. Alveolar spaces were filled with many alveolar macrophages and cholesterol clefts. Scattered inflammatory cells consisting of plasma cells, eosinophils, and occasional neutrophils were seen. Disorganized lamellar bodies on electron microscopy.
member.previousTestingDescription: Genetic testing was negative for mutations in ABCA3 and SFTPB

evidence.rdfs:label: Fattori Family 1

member.rdfs:label: Fattori Proband 1
member.phenotypeFreeText: Proband underwent a bilateral lung transplant, and was diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. At the time of transplantation revealed increased diffuse interstitial markings, with significant apical involvement, causing bilateral volume loss and shaggy outline of the mediastinum. Results of pulmonary function tests yielded a restrictive pattern with decreased FVC and decreased total lung capacity (69% and 47% of predicted, respectively). The FEV1/FVC ratio was 86%, and carbon monoxide transfer coefficient was 36% of predicted. BAL cellular analysis consisted of macrophages (66%), lymphocytes (19%; CD4+/CD8+ ratio, 0.16), neutrophils (10%), and eosinophils (5%). HRCT imaging confirmed extensive interlobular/intralobular reticulations with subpleural predominance, causing architectural distortion and irregular fissures. Subpleural cysts and paraseptal emphysematous changes were seen in the apices.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Probands nonsmoker father presented with lung cancer at 59 years of age.

member.rdfs:label: Peca Proband 8
member.phenotypeFreeText: Severe respiratory distress syndrome at birth. 2 doses of surfactant. HRCT imaging found overexpansion and bronchial markings.

evidence.dc:description: "Using a candidate gene approach, we found a heterozygous exon 5 + 128 T→A transversion of SFTPC in a large familial pulmonary fibrosis kindred"
evidence.rdfs:label: Thomas FPF Kindred

member.rdfs:label: Thomas Patient III:3
member.phenotypeFreeText: Chest x-ray showed diffuse coarse reticulation with multiple lucencies. Had a double lung transplant. Pathology patterns of UIP. Lung biopsy shows coarse scarring with airspace dilatation and metaplastic cuboidal to columnar epithelium, normal alveolar tissue, and two fibroblast foci at the interface. Immunostaining for proSP-C was evident without antigen retrieval within rows of abnormal type II cells lining thickened alveoli and terminal airways. Large, dysplastic, cuboidal type II cells were seen proliferating throughout affected areas of lung. Staining for proSP-C revealed diffuse cytoplasmic distribution in type II cells.

member.rdfs:label: Proband URD23
member.phenotypeFreeText: Deceased at age 18 months. "This subpopulation who did not have evidence for lung disease, we propose environmental exposures or modifier genes to play a role in the phenotype"
member.previousTestingDescription: SFTPB mutation leading to SP-B deficiency had been ruled out

evidence.dc:description: This variant has a MAF=0.00002319 (2/86258 with 0 homozygotes) in the South Asian population from gnomAD v4.1.0.
Immunolabeling studies showed increased proSP-C staining in all cases.

During fetal development, SFTPC C121G expression resulted in a toxic gain-of-function causing fatal postnatal respiratory failure from disrupted lung morphogenesis. In adult mice, SFTPC C121G expression resulted in an ER-retained pro-protein causing AT2 cell ER stress. SFTPC C121G mice developed spontaneous pulmonary fibrosis and restrictive lung impairment, with many of the features of adult and pediatric interstitial lung disease recapitulated including lung histology of distorted architecture, enlargement of airspaces, interstitial widening, inflammatory infiltrate, and proteinacious fluid in the airspaces.
evidence.rdfs:label: SFTPC BRICHOS C121G KI Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: The inflammatory phenotype observed early and heterozygous mice had mild alveolitis and inflammatory histological changes 2 weeks after induction but failed to yield to frank fibrosis.

The mutant heterozygous SftpcI73T knockin mouse showed toxic gain-of-function and features of the human IPF phenotypes including: lung fibrosis, abnormal lung morphology, and played a critical role of how AT2 cell dysfunction as a key upstream driver of IPF pathogenesis and early lung injury.
evidence.rdfs:label: Spontaneous lung fibrosis expression

evidence.dc:description: A variety of studies implicate ER stress as an important factor in progression of a variety of chronic, fibrotic diseases, including IPF. In the lung, ER stress appears to primarily localize in AECs, where this pathway has been linked to increased AEC apoptosis, as well as other pro-fibrotic phenotypic characteristics. In addition, ER stress in other cell types, including fibroblasts and macrophages, can affect pro-fibrotic responses by these cells.

With expression of L188Q SFTPC and resultant ER stress, AECs were more prone to apoptosis after bleomycin treatment, and greater numbers of lung fibroblasts were observed, findings that could explain enhanced fibrosis in the mutant L188Q SFTPC mice.
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression of L188Q SFTPC induced ER stress

evidence.dc:description: Specifically expressed only in the lung and no other tissues.
This gene is highly expressed in the lung.
evidence.rdfs:label: Tissue Expression in SFTPC
